# The Star-Spangled Banner

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

"Star-Spangled Banner" and "National anthem of the USA" redirect here. For the
flag that flew over Fort McHenry, see [Star-Spangled Banner
(flag)](/wiki/Star-Spangled_Banner_\(flag\) "Star-Spangled Banner \(flag\)").
For the present flag, see [Flag of the United
States](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the United States"). For the
national anthem of the Union of South Africa, see [Die Stem van Suid-
Afrika](/wiki/Die_Stem_van_Suid-Afrika "Die Stem van Suid-Afrika").

"**The Star-Spangled Banner** " is the [national anthem](/wiki/National_anthem
"National anthem") of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States"). The lyrics come from **Defence of Fort M 'Henry**,[2] a
[poem](/wiki/Poem "Poem") written on September 14, 1814, by the then 35-year-
old lawyer and amateur poet [Francis Scott Key](/wiki/Francis_Scott_Key
"Francis Scott Key") after witnessing the bombardment of [Fort
McHenry](/wiki/Fort_McHenry "Fort McHenry") by British ships of the [Royal
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") in Baltimore Harbor during the [Battle of
Baltimore](/wiki/Battle_of_Baltimore "Battle of Baltimore") in the [War of
1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"). Key was inspired by the large [U.S.
flag](/wiki/U.S._flag "U.S. flag"), with 15 stars and 15 stripes, known as the
[Star-Spangled Banner](/wiki/Star-Spangled_Banner_\(flag\) "Star-Spangled
Banner \(flag\)"), flying triumphantly above the fort during the U.S. victory.

The poem was set to the tune of a popular British song written by [John
Stafford Smith](/wiki/John_Stafford_Smith "John Stafford Smith") for the
[Anacreontic Society](/wiki/Anacreontic_Society "Anacreontic Society"), a
men's social club in London. "[To Anacreon in
Heaven](/wiki/To_Anacreon_in_Heaven "To Anacreon in Heaven")" (or "The
Anacreontic Song"), with various lyrics, was already popular in the United
States. Set to Key's poem and renamed "The Star-Spangled Banner", it soon
became a well-known U.S. patriotic song. With a [range](/wiki/Range_\(music\)
"Range \(music\)") of 19 semitones, it is known for being very difficult to
sing. Although the poem has four [stanzas](/wiki/Stanza "Stanza"), only the
first is commonly sung today.

"The Star-Spangled Banner" was recognized for official use by the [United
States Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") in 1889, and by
U.S. President [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson") in
1916, and was made the national anthem by a
[congressional](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress")
[resolution](/wiki/Resolution_\(law\) "Resolution \(law\)") on March 3, 1931
(46 Stat. 1508, codified at [36
U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_36_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 36 of the United
States Code") [§ 301](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/301)), which
was signed by President [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert
Hoover").

Before 1931, other songs served as the hymns of U.S. officialdom. "[Hail,
Columbia](/wiki/Hail,_Columbia "Hail, Columbia")" served this purpose at
official functions for most of the 19th century. "[My Country, 'Tis of
Thee](/wiki/My_Country,_%27Tis_of_Thee "My Country, 'Tis of Thee")", whose
melody is identical to "[God Save the Queen](/wiki/God_Save_the_Queen "God
Save the Queen")", the United Kingdom's national anthem,[3] also served as a
_de facto_ national anthem.[4] Following the War of 1812 and subsequent U.S.
wars, other songs emerged to compete for popularity at public events, among
them "[America the Beautiful](/wiki/America_the_Beautiful "America the
Beautiful")".

## Early history

### Francis Scott Key's lyrics

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/KeysSSB.jpg/170px-
KeysSSB.jpg)](/wiki/File:KeysSSB.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:KeysSSB.jpg "Enlarge")

[Francis Scott Key](/wiki/Francis_Scott_Key "Francis Scott Key")'s original
manuscript copy of his "Defence of Fort M'Henry" poem. It is now on display at
the [Maryland Historical Society](/wiki/Maryland_Historical_Society "Maryland
Historical Society").

On September 3, 1814, following the [Burning of
Washington](/wiki/Burning_of_Washington "Burning of Washington") and the [Raid
on Alexandria](/wiki/Raid_on_Alexandria "Raid on Alexandria"), Francis Scott
Key and [John Stuart Skinner](/wiki/John_Stuart_Skinner "John Stuart Skinner")
set sail from [Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore") aboard the ship [HMS
_Minden_](/wiki/HMS_Minden "HMS Minden"), flying a [flag of
truce](/wiki/White_flag "White flag") on a mission approved by [President
James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison"). Their objective was to
secure an exchange of prisoners, one of whom was [Dr. William
Beanes](/wiki/William_Beanes "William Beanes"), the elderly and popular town
physician of [Upper Marlboro](/wiki/Upper_Marlboro,_Maryland "Upper Marlboro,
Maryland") and a friend of Key's who had been captured in his home. Beanes was
accused of aiding the arrest of British soldiers. Key and Skinner boarded the
British [flagship](/wiki/Flagship "Flagship") [HMS
_Tonnant_](/wiki/HMS_Tonnant "HMS Tonnant") on September 7 and spoke with
Major General [Robert Ross](/wiki/Robert_Ross_\(general\) "Robert Ross
\(general\)") and Vice Admiral [Alexander Cochrane](/wiki/Alexander_Cochrane
"Alexander Cochrane") over dinner while the two officers discussed war plans.
At first, Ross and Cochrane refused to release Beanes but relented after Key
and Skinner showed them letters written by wounded British prisoners praising
Beanes and other Americans for their kind treatment.

Because Key and Skinner had heard details of the plans for [the attack on
Baltimore](/wiki/Battle_of_Baltimore "Battle of Baltimore"), they were held
captive until after the battle, first aboard [HMS
_Surprise_](/wiki/HMS_Surprise_\(1812\) "HMS Surprise \(1812\)") and later
back on HMS _Minden_. After the bombardment, certain British gunboats
attempted to slip past the fort and effect a landing in a cove to the west of
it, but they were turned away by fire from nearby Fort Covington, the city's
last line of defense.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Ft._Henry_bombardement_1814.jpg/220px-
Ft._Henry_bombardement_1814.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ft._Henry_bombardement_1814.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ft._Henry_bombardement_1814.jpg "Enlarge")

An artist's rendering of the battle at [Fort McHenry](/wiki/Fort_McHenry "Fort
McHenry")

During the rainy night, Key had witnessed the bombardment and observed that
the [fort](/wiki/Fortress "Fortress")'s smaller "storm flag" continued to fly,
but once the shell and [Congreve rocket](/wiki/Congreve_rocket "Congreve
rocket")[5] barrage had stopped, he would not know how the battle had turned
out until dawn. On the morning of September 14, the storm flag had been
lowered and the larger flag had been raised.

During the bombardment, [HMS _Terror_](/wiki/HMS_Terror_\(1813\) "HMS Terror
\(1813\)") and [HMS _Meteor_](/wiki/HMS_Starr_\(1805\) "HMS Starr \(1805\)")
provided some of the "bombs bursting in air".

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Star_Spangled_Banner_Flag_on_display_at_the_Smithsonian%27s_National_Museum_of_History_and_Technology%2C_around_1964.jpg/170px-
Star_Spangled_Banner_Flag_on_display_at_the_Smithsonian%27s_National_Museum_of_History_and_Technology%2C_around_1964.jpg)](/wiki/File:Star_Spangled_Banner_Flag_on_display_at_the_Smithsonian%27s_National_Museum_of_History_and_Technology,_around_1964.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Star_Spangled_Banner_Flag_on_display_at_the_Smithsonian%27s_National_Museum_of_History_and_Technology,_around_1964.jpg
"Enlarge")

The 15-star, 15-stripe "[Star-Spangled Banner](/wiki/Star-
Spangled_Banner_\(flag\) "Star-Spangled Banner \(flag\)")" that inspired the
poem

Key was inspired by the U.S. victory and the sight of the large [U.S.
flag](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the United States") flying
triumphantly above the fort. This flag, with fifteen stars and fifteen
stripes, had been made by [Mary Young Pickersgill](/wiki/Mary_Pickersgill
"Mary Pickersgill") together with other workers in her home on Baltimore's
Pratt Street. The flag later came to be known as the [Star-Spangled
Banner](/wiki/Star-Spangled_Banner_\(flag\) "Star-Spangled Banner \(flag\)")
and is today on display in the [National Museum of American
History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_American_History "National Museum of
American History"), a treasure of the [Smithsonian
Institution](/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution "Smithsonian Institution"). It was
restored in 1914 by [Amelia Fowler](/wiki/Amelia_Fowler "Amelia Fowler"), and
again in 1998 as part of an ongoing conservation program.

Aboard the ship the next day, Key wrote a poem on the back of a letter he had
kept in his pocket. At twilight on September 16, he and Skinner were released
in Baltimore. He completed the poem at the Indian Queen Hotel, where he was
staying, and titled it "Defence of Fort M'Henry". It was first published
nationally in _[The Analectic Magazine](/wiki/Analectic_Magazine "Analectic
Magazine")_.[6][7]

Much of the idea of the poem, including the flag imagery and some of the
wording, is derived from an earlier song by Key, also set to the tune of "[The
Anacreontic Song](/wiki/The_Anacreontic_Song "The Anacreontic Song")". The
song, known as "When the Warrior Returns",[8] was written in honor of [Stephen
Decatur](/wiki/Stephen_Decatur "Stephen Decatur") and [Charles
Stewart](/wiki/Charles_Stewart_\(1778%E2%80%931869\) "Charles Stewart
\(1778–1869\)") on their return from the [First Barbary
War](/wiki/First_Barbary_War "First Barbary War").  Absent elaboration by
Francis Scott Key prior to his death in 1843, some have speculated in modern
times about the meaning of phrases or verses. According to British historian
[Robin Blackburn](/wiki/Robin_Blackburn "Robin Blackburn"), the words "the
hireling and slave" allude to the thousands of ex-slaves in the British ranks
organised as the Corps of Colonial Marines, who had been liberated by the
British and demanded to be placed in the battle line "where they might expect
to meet their former masters."[9] Nevertheless, Professor Mark Clague, a
professor of [musicology](/wiki/Musicology "Musicology") at the [University of
Michigan](/wiki/University_of_Michigan "University of Michigan"), argues that
the "middle two verses of Key's lyric vilify the British enemy in the War of
1812" and "in no way glorifies or celebrates slavery."[10] Clague writes that
"For Key ... the British mercenaries were scoundrels and the Colonial Marines
were traitors who threatened to spark a national insurrection."[10] This
harshly anti-British nature of Verse 3 led to its omission in [sheet
music](/wiki/Sheet_music "Sheet music") in World War I, when the British and
the U.S. were allies.[10] Responding to the assertion of writer Jon Schwarz of
_[The Intercept](/wiki/The_Intercept "The Intercept")_ that the song is a
"celebration of slavery,"[11] Clague said that: "The reference to slaves is
about the use and in some sense the manipulation, of black Americans to fight
for the British, with the promise of freedom. The American forces included
African-Americans as well as whites. The term 'freemen,' whose heroism is
celebrated in the fourth stanza, would have encompassed both."[12]

Others suggest that "Key may have intended the phrase as a reference to the
British Navy's practice of [impressment](/wiki/Impressment "Impressment")
(kidnapping sailors and forcing them to fight in defense of the crown), or as
a semi-metaphorical slap at the British invading force as a whole (which
included a large number of mercenaries)."[13]

### John Stafford Smith's music

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/2_Star_Spangled_Banner.png/170px-2_Star_Spangled_Banner.png)](/wiki/File:2_Star_Spangled_Banner.png)

[](/wiki/File:2_Star_Spangled_Banner.png "Enlarge")

Sheet music version [![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:2_Star_Spangled_Banner.mid "About this
sound")
[Play](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ec/2_Star_Spangled_Banner.mid
"2 Star Spangled Banner.mid") ([help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media help")·[info](/wiki/File:2_Star_Spangled_Banner.mid "File:2
Star Spangled Banner.mid"))

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/JohnStaffordSmith01.jpg/220px-
JohnStaffordSmith01.jpg)](/wiki/File:JohnStaffordSmith01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JohnStaffordSmith01.jpg "Enlarge")

The memorial to [John Stafford Smith](/wiki/John_Stafford_Smith "John Stafford
Smith") in [Gloucester Cathedral](/wiki/Gloucester_Cathedral "Gloucester
Cathedral"), [Gloucester](/wiki/Gloucester "Gloucester"), England

Key gave the poem to his brother-in-law Judge Joseph H. Nicholson who saw that
the words fit the popular melody "[The Anacreontic
Song](/wiki/The_Anacreontic_Song "The Anacreontic Song")", by English composer
[John Stafford Smith](/wiki/John_Stafford_Smith "John Stafford Smith"). This
was the official song of the [Anacreontic Society](/wiki/Anacreontic_Society
"Anacreontic Society"), an 18th-century gentlemen's club of amateur musicians
in London. Nicholson took the poem to a printer in Baltimore, who anonymously
made the first known [broadside](/wiki/Broadside_\(music\) "Broadside
\(music\)") printing on September 17; of these, two known copies survive.

On September 20, both the _Baltimore Patriot_ and _The American_ printed the
song, with the note "Tune: Anacreon in Heaven". The song quickly became
popular, with seventeen newspapers from Georgia to New Hampshire printing it.
Soon after, Thomas Carr of the Carr Music Store in Baltimore published the
words and music together under the title "The Star Spangled Banner", although
it was originally called "Defence of Fort M'Henry". Thomas Carr's arrangement
introduced the raised fourth which became the standard deviation from "The
Anacreontic Song".[14] The song's popularity increased and its first public
performance took place in October when Baltimore actor [Ferdinand
Durang](/wiki/Ferdinand_Durang "Ferdinand Durang") sang it at Captain
McCauley's [tavern](/wiki/Tavern "Tavern"). [Washington
Irving](/wiki/Washington_Irving "Washington Irving"), then editor of the
_[Analectic Magazine](/wiki/Analectic_Magazine "Analectic Magazine")_ in
Philadelphia, reprinted the song in November 1814.

By the early 20th century, there were various versions of the song in popular
use. Seeking a singular, standard version, President Woodrow Wilson tasked the
U.S. Bureau of Education with providing that official version. In response,
the Bureau enlisted the help of five musicians to agree upon an arrangement.
Those musicians were [Walter Damrosch](/wiki/Walter_Damrosch "Walter
Damrosch"), [Will Earhart](/wiki/Will_Earhart "Will Earhart"), Arnold J.
Gantvoort, [Oscar Sonneck](/wiki/Oscar_Sonneck "Oscar Sonneck") and [John
Philip Sousa](/wiki/John_Philip_Sousa "John Philip Sousa"). The standardized
version that was voted upon by these five musicians premiered at [Carnegie
Hall](/wiki/Carnegie_Hall "Carnegie Hall") on December 5, 1917, in a program
that included [Edward Elgar](/wiki/Edward_Elgar "Edward Elgar")'s _Carillon_
and [Gabriel Pierné](/wiki/Gabriel_Piern%C3%A9 "Gabriel Pierné")'s _The
Children 's Crusade_. The concert was put on by the [Oratorio Society of New
York](/wiki/Oratorio_Society_of_New_York "Oratorio Society of New York") and
conducted by Walter Damrosch.[15] An official handwritten version of the final
votes of these five men has been found and shows all five men's votes tallied,
measure by measure.[16]

### National anthem

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Star-
Spangled_Banner_plaque.JPG/220px-Star-
Spangled_Banner_plaque.JPG)](/wiki/File:Star-Spangled_Banner_plaque.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Star-Spangled_Banner_plaque.JPG "Enlarge")

[Commemorative plaque](/wiki/Commemorative_plaque "Commemorative plaque") in
Washington, D.C. marking the site at 601 [Pennsylvania
Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue_\(Washington,_D.C.\) "Pennsylvania Avenue
\(Washington, D.C.\)") where "The Star-Spangled Banner" was first publicly
sung

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Defence_of_Fort_M%27Henry_broadside.jpg/220px-
Defence_of_Fort_M%27Henry_broadside.jpg)](/wiki/File:Defence_of_Fort_M%27Henry_broadside.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Defence_of_Fort_M%27Henry_broadside.jpg "Enlarge")

One of two surviving copies of the 1814 broadside printing of the "Defence of
Fort M'Henry", a poem that later became the lyrics of "The Star-Spangled
Banner", the national anthem of the United States.

The song gained popularity throughout the 19th century and bands played it
during public events, such as [Independence
Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_\(United_States\) "Independence Day \(United
States\)") celebrations.

A plaque displayed at Fort Meade, South Dakota, claims that the idea of making
"The Star Spangled Banner" the national anthem began on their parade ground in
1892. Colonel Caleb Carlton, Post Commander, established the tradition that
the song be played "at retreat and at the close of parades and concerts."
Carlton explained the custom to Governor Sheldon of South Dakota who "promised
me that he would try to have the custom established among the state militia."
Carlton wrote that after a similar discussion, Secretary of War, Daniel E.
Lamont issued an order that it "be played at every Army post every evening at
retreat."[17]

In 1899, the U.S. Navy officially adopted "The Star-Spangled Banner".[18] In
1916, President [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson")
ordered that "The Star-Spangled Banner" be played at military[18] and other
appropriate occasions. The playing of the song two years later during the
[seventh-inning stretch](/wiki/Seventh-inning_stretch "Seventh-inning
stretch") of Game One of the [1918 World Series](/wiki/1918_World_Series "1918
World Series"), and thereafter during each game of the series is often cited
as the first instance that the anthem was played at a baseball game,[19]
though evidence shows that the "Star-Spangled Banner" was performed as early
as 1897 at opening day ceremonies in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia
"Philadelphia") and then more regularly at the [Polo
Grounds](/wiki/Polo_Grounds "Polo Grounds") in New York City beginning in
1898. In any case, the tradition of performing the national anthem before
_every_ baseball game began in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War
II").[20]

On April 10, 1918, [John Charles Linthicum](/wiki/John_Charles_Linthicum "John
Charles Linthicum"), U.S. Congressman from Maryland, introduced a bill to
officially recognize "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national anthem.[21]
The bill did not pass.[21] On April 15, 1929, Linthicum introduced the bill
again, his sixth time doing so.[21] On November 3, 1929, [Robert
Ripley](/wiki/Robert_Ripley "Robert Ripley") drew a panel in his syndicated
cartoon, _[Ripley's Believe it or Not!](/wiki/Ripley%27s_Believe_it_or_Not!
"Ripley's Believe it or Not!")_, saying "Believe It or Not, America has no
national anthem".[22]

In 1930, [Veterans of Foreign Wars](/wiki/Veterans_of_Foreign_Wars "Veterans
of Foreign Wars") started a petition for the United States to officially
recognize "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national anthem.[23] Five million
people signed the petition.[23] The petition was presented to the [United
States House Committee on the
Judiciary](/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary "United States
House Committee on the Judiciary") on January 31, 1930.[24] On the same day,
Elsie Jorss-Reilley and Grace Evelyn Boudlin sang the song to the Committee to
refute the perception that it was too high pitched for a typical person to
sing.[25] The Committee voted in favor of sending the bill to the House floor
for a vote.[26] The [House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives") passed the bill later that year.[27] The
[Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") passed the bill on
March 3, 1931.[27] [President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States_of_America
"President of the United States of America") [Herbert
Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert Hoover") signed the bill on March 4,
1931, officially adopting "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national anthem of
the United States of America.[1] As currently codified, the [United States
Code](/wiki/United_States_Code "United States Code") states that "[t]he
composition consisting of the words and music known as the Star-Spangled
Banner is the national anthem."[28]

### Performances

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Usnationalanthemcrowd.jpg/170px-
Usnationalanthemcrowd.jpg)](/wiki/File:Usnationalanthemcrowd.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Usnationalanthemcrowd.jpg "Enlarge")

Crowd performing the U.S. national anthem before a baseball game at [Coors
Field](/wiki/Coors_Field "Coors Field")

The song is notoriously difficult for nonprofessionals to sing because of its
wide range – a [12th](/wiki/Interval_\(music\) "Interval \(music\)"). Humorist
[Richard Armour](/wiki/Richard_Armour_\(poet\) "Richard Armour \(poet\)")
referred to the song's difficulty in his book _It All Started With Columbus_.

> In an attempt to take Baltimore, the British attacked Fort McHenry, which
> protected the harbor. Bombs were soon bursting in air, rockets were glaring,
> and all in all it was a moment of great historical interest. During the
> bombardment, a young lawyer named Francis Off Key  [_[sic](/wiki/Sic
> "Sic")_] wrote "The Star-Spangled Banner", and when, by the dawn's early
> light, the British heard it sung, they fled in terror.
>
> — Richard Armour

Professional and amateur singers have been known to forget the words, which is
one reason the song is sometimes pre-recorded and lip-synced.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Other
times the issue is avoided by having the performer(s) play the anthem
instrumentally instead of singing it. The pre-recording of the anthem has
become standard practice at some ballparks, such as Boston's [Fenway
Park](/wiki/Fenway_Park "Fenway Park"), according to the [SABR](/wiki/SABR
"SABR") publication _The Fenway Project_.[29]

"The Star-Spangled Banner" has been performed regularly at the beginning of
[NFL](/wiki/NFL "NFL") games since the end of [WWII](/wiki/WWII "WWII") by
order of NFL commissioner [Elmer Layden](/wiki/Elmer_Layden "Elmer Layden"),
according to History.com .[30] According to same article, the song has been
intermittently performed at baseball games since after [WWI](/wiki/WWI "WWI")
It has also been popular as performed by orchestra or soloists at other public
gatherings. The [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League
"National Hockey League") and [Major League Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer
"Major League Soccer") both require venues in both the U.S. and Canada to
perform both the [Canadian](/wiki/O_Canada "O Canada") and U.S. national
anthems at games that involve teams from both countries (with the "away"
anthem being performed first).[31][_[better source
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_] It is also usual for both
U.S. and Canadian anthems (done in the same way as the NHL and MLS) to be
played at [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") and [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") games involving the [Toronto Blue Jays](/wiki/Toronto_Blue_Jays
"Toronto Blue Jays") and the [Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto
Raptors") (respectively), the only Canadian teams in those two major U.S.
sports leagues, and in All Star Games on the MLB, NBA, and NHL. The [Buffalo
Sabres](/wiki/Buffalo_Sabres "Buffalo Sabres") of the NHL, which play in a
city on the [Canada–US border](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border
"Canada–United States border") and have a substantial Canadian fan base, play
both anthems before all home games regardless of where the visiting team is
based.[32]

Two especially unusual performances of the song took place in the immediate
aftermath of the United States [September 11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"). On September 12,
2001, [the Queen](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") broke with tradition and
allowed the [Band of the Coldstream
Guards](/wiki/Band_of_the_Coldstream_Guards "Band of the Coldstream Guards")
to perform the anthem at [Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace
"Buckingham Palace"), London, at the ceremonial Changing of the Guard, as a
gesture of support for Britain's ally.[33] The following day at a St. Paul's
Cathedral memorial service, the Queen joined in the singing of the anthem, an
unprecedented occurrence.[34]

### 200th anniversary celebrations

The 200th anniversary of the "Star-Spangled Banner" occurred in 2014 with
various special events occurring throughout the United States. A particularly
significant celebration occurred during the week of September 10–16 in and
around Baltimore, Maryland. Highlights included playing of a new arrangement
of the anthem arranged by John Williams and participation of President Obama
on [Defender's Day](/wiki/Defenders_Day "Defenders Day"), September 12, 2014,
at Fort McHenry.[35] In addition, the anthem bicentennial included a youth
music celebration[36] including the presentation of the National Anthem
Bicentennial Youth Challenge winning composition written by Noah Altshuler.

_O 'er the ramparts we watch_ in a 1945 [United States Army Air

The first [popular music](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music") performance of
the anthem heard by the mainstream U.S. was by [Puerto
Rican](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") singer and guitarist [José
Feliciano](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Feliciano "José Feliciano"). He created a
nationwide uproar when he strummed a slow, [blues](/wiki/Blues "Blues")-style
rendition of the song[37] at [Tiger Stadium](/wiki/Tiger_Stadium_\(Detroit\)
"Tiger Stadium \(Detroit\)") in Detroit before game five of the [1968 World
Series](/wiki/1968_World_Series "1968 World Series"), between
[Detroit](/wiki/Detroit_Tigers "Detroit Tigers") and [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals").[38] This rendition
started contemporary "Star-Spangled Banner" controversies. The response from
many in the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War")-era U.S. was
generally negative. Despite the controversy, Feliciano's performance opened
the door for the countless interpretations of the "Star-Spangled Banner" heard
in the years since.[39] One week after Feliciano's performance, the anthem was
in the news again when U.S. athletes [Tommie Smith](/wiki/Tommie_Smith "Tommie
Smith") and [John Carlos](/wiki/John_Carlos "John Carlos") lifted
controversial [raised fists at the 1968
Olympics](/wiki/1968_Olympics_Black_Power_salute "1968 Olympics Black Power
salute") while the "Star-Spangled Banner" played at a medal ceremony.

[Marvin Gaye](/wiki/Marvin_Gaye "Marvin Gaye") gave a [soul](/wiki/Soul_music
"Soul music")-influenced performance at the [1983 NBA All-Star
Game](/wiki/1983_NBA_All-Star_Game "1983 NBA All-Star Game") and [Whitney
Houston](/wiki/Whitney_Houston "Whitney Houston") gave a soulful rendition
before [Super Bowl XXV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXV "Super Bowl XXV") in 1991, which
was released as a single that charted at number 20 in 1991 and number 6 in
2001 (along with [José Feliciano](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Feliciano "José Feliciano"),
the only times the national anthem has been on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")). In 1993, Kiss did an
instrumental rock version as the closing track on their album, _Alive III_.
Another famous instrumental interpretation is [Jimi
Hendrix](/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix "Jimi Hendrix")'s version, which was a set-list
staple from autumn 1968 until his death in September 1970, including a famous
rendition at the [Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock "Woodstock") music festival in
1969. Incorporating [sonic effects](/wiki/Reverberation "Reverberation") to
emphasize the "rockets' red glare", and "bombs bursting in air", it became a
late-1960s emblem. [Roseanne Barr](/wiki/Roseanne_Barr "Roseanne Barr") gave a
controversial performance of the anthem at a [San Diego
Padres](/wiki/San_Diego_Padres "San Diego Padres") baseball game at [Jack
Murphy Stadium](/wiki/Jack_Murphy_Stadium "Jack Murphy Stadium") on July 25,
1990. The comedian belted out a screechy rendition of the song, and afterward,
she attempted a gesture of ballplayers by spitting and grabbing her crotch as
if adjusting a protective cup. The performance offended some, including the
sitting U.S. President, [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H.
W. Bush").[40] [Sufjan Stevens](/wiki/Sufjan_Stevens "Sufjan Stevens") has
frequently performed the "Star-Spangled Banner" in live sets, replacing the
optimism in the end of the first verse with a new coda that alludes to the
divisive state of the nation today. [David Lee Roth](/wiki/David_Lee_Roth
"David Lee Roth") both referenced parts of the anthem and played part of a
hard rock rendition of the anthem on his song, "[Yankee
Rose](/wiki/Yankee_Rose_\(song\) "Yankee Rose \(song\)")" on his 1986 solo
album, _[Eat'Em and Smile](/wiki/Eat_%27Em_and_Smile "Eat 'Em and Smile")_.
[Steven Tyler](/wiki/Steven_Tyler "Steven Tyler") also caused some controversy
in 2001 (at the [Indianapolis 500](/wiki/Indianapolis_500 "Indianapolis 500"),
to which he later issued a public apology) and again in 2012 (at the [AFC
Championship Game](/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC Championship Game")) with
[a cappella](/wiki/A_cappella "A cappella") renditions of the song with
changed lyrics.[41] In 2016, [Aretha Franklin](/wiki/Aretha_Franklin "Aretha
Franklin") performed a rendition before the nationally-televised [Minnesota
Vikings-Detroit Lions](/wiki/Lions%E2%80%93Vikings_rivalry "Lions–Vikings
rivalry") Thanksgiving Day game lasting more than four minutes and featuring a
host of improvizations. It would be one of Franklin's last public appearances
before her 2018 death.[42] [Black Eyed Peas](/wiki/Black-eyed_Peas "Black-eyed
Peas")-singer [Fergie](/wiki/Fergie_\(singer\) "Fergie \(singer\)") gave a
controversial performance of the anthem in 2018. Critics likened her rendition
to a jazzy "sexed-up" version of the anthem, which was considered highly
inappropriate, with her performance compared to that of [Marilyn
Monroe](/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe "Marilyn Monroe")'s iconic performance of [Happy
Birthday, Mr. President](/wiki/Happy_Birthday,_Mr._President "Happy Birthday,
Mr. President"). Fergie later apologized for her performance of the song,
citing that ''I'm a risk taker artistically, but clearly this rendition didn't
strike the intended tone".[43]

A version of [Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith "Aerosmith")'s [Joe
Perry](/wiki/Joe_Perry_\(musician\) "Joe Perry \(musician\)") and [Brad
Whitford](/wiki/Brad_Whitford "Brad Whitford") playing part of the song can be
heard at the end of their version of "[Train Kept
A-Rollin'](/wiki/Train_Kept_A-Rollin%27 "Train Kept A-Rollin'")" on the
_[Rockin' the Joint](/wiki/Rockin%27_the_Joint "Rockin' the Joint")_ album.
The band [Boston](/wiki/Boston_\(band\) "Boston \(band\)") gave an
instrumental rock rendition of the anthem on their _[Greatest
Hits](/wiki/Greatest_Hits_\(Boston_album\) "Greatest Hits \(Boston album\)")_
album. The band [Crush 40](/wiki/Crush_40 "Crush 40") made a version of the
song as opening track from the album _[Thrill of the
Feel](/wiki/Thrill_of_the_Feel "Thrill of the Feel")_ (2000).

In March 2005, a government-sponsored program, the [National Anthem
Project](/wiki/National_Anthem_Project "National Anthem Project"), was
launched after a [Harris Interactive](/wiki/Harris_Insights_%26_Analytics
"Harris Insights & Analytics") poll showed many adults knew neither the lyrics
nor the history of the anthem.[44]

## Lyrics

> O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,  
>  What so proudly we hailed at the twilight's last gleaming,  
>  Whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fight,  
>  O'er the ramparts we watched, were so gallantly streaming?  
>  And the rockets' red glare, the bombs bursting in air,  
>  Gave proof through the night that our flag was still there;  
>  O say does that star-spangled banner yet wave  
>  O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave?  
>  
>  On the shore dimly seen through the mists of the deep,  
>  Where the foe's haughty host in dread silence reposes,  
>  What is that which the breeze, o'er the towering steep,  
>  As it fitfully blows, half conceals, half discloses?  
>  Now it catches the gleam of the morning's first beam,  
>  In full glory reflected now shines in the stream:  
>  'Tis the star-spangled banner, O long may it wave  
>  O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave.

>  That the havoc of war and the battle's confusion,

>  Their blood has washed out their foul footsteps' pollution.  
>  No refuge could save the hireling and slave

>  Blest with vict'ry and peace, may the Heav'n rescued land

### Additional Civil War period lyrics

Eighteen years after Key's death, and in indignation over the start of the
[American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"), [Oliver
Wendell Holmes, Sr.](/wiki/Oliver_Wendell_Holmes,_Sr. "Oliver Wendell Holmes,
Sr.")[46] added a fifth stanza to the song in 1861, which appeared in
songbooks of the era.[47]

> When our land is illumined with Liberty's smile,  
>  If a foe from within strike a blow at her glory,  
>  Down, down with the traitor that dares to defile  
>  The flag of her stars and the page of her story!  
>  By the millions unchained, who our birthright have gained,  
>  We will keep her bright blazon forever unstained!  
>  And the Star-Spangled Banner in triumph shall wave  
>  While the land of the free is the home of the brave.

#### Alternative lyrics

In a version hand-written by Francis Scott Key in 1840, the third line reads
"Whose bright stars and broad stripes, through the clouds of the fight".[48]
In honour of [the 1986 rededication of the Statue of
Liberty](/wiki/Liberty_Weekend "Liberty Weekend"), [Sandi
Patty](/wiki/Sandi_Patty "Sandi Patty") wrote her version of an additional
verse to the anthem.[49]

## References in film, television, literature

Several films have their titles taken from the song's lyrics. These include
two films titled _Dawn 's Early Light_ (2000[50] and 2005);[51] two [made-for-
TV](/wiki/Television_movie "Television movie") features titled _By Dawn 's
Early Light_ ([1990](/wiki/By_Dawn%27s_Early_Light "By Dawn's Early
Light")[52] and 2000);[53] two films titled _So Proudly We Hail_
([1943](/wiki/So_Proudly_We_Hail! "So Proudly We Hail!")[54] and 1990);[55] a
[feature film](/wiki/Twilight%27s_Last_Gleaming "Twilight's Last Gleaming")
(1977)[56] and a [short](/wiki/Short_film "Short film") (2005)[57] titled
_Twilight 's Last Gleaming_; and four films titled _Home of the Brave_
([1949](/wiki/Home_of_the_Brave_\(1949_film\) "Home of the Brave \(1949
film\)"),[58] [1986](/wiki/Home_of_the_Brave_\(1986_film\) "Home of the Brave
\(1986 film\)"),[59] [2004](/wiki/Home_of_the_Brave_\(2004_film\) "Home of the
Brave \(2004 film\)"),[60] and [2006](/wiki/Home_of_the_Brave_\(2006_film\)
"Home of the Brave \(2006 film\)")).[61] A 1936 short titled _The Song of a
Nation_ from Warner Brothers shows a version of the origin of the song.[62]

## Customs and federal law

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Star_Spangled_Banner_Plaque.jpg/170px-
Star_Spangled_Banner_Plaque.jpg)](/wiki/File:Star_Spangled_Banner_Plaque.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Star_Spangled_Banner_Plaque.jpg "Enlarge")

Plaque detailing how the custom of standing during the U.S. national anthem
came about in Tacoma, Washington, on October 18, 1893, in the Bostwick
building

When the U.S. national anthem was first recognized by law in 1931, there was
no prescription as to behavior during its playing. On June 22, 1942, the law
was revised indicating that those in uniform should salute during its playing,
while others should simply stand at attention, men removing their hats. The
same code also required that women should place their hands over their hearts
when the flag is displayed during the playing of the national anthem, but not
if the flag was not present. On December 23, 1942, the law was again revised
instructing men and women to stand at attention and face in the direction of
the music when it was played. That revision also directed men and women to
place their hands over their hearts only if the flag was displayed. Those in
uniform were required to salute. On July 7, 1976, the law was simplified. Men
and women were instructed to stand with their hands over their hearts, men
removing their hats, irrespective of whether or not the flag was displayed and
those in uniform saluting. On August 12, 1998, the law was rewritten keeping
the same instructions, but differentiating between "those in uniform" and
"members of the Armed Forces and veterans" who were both instructed to salute
during the playing whether or not the flag was displayed. Because of the
changes in law over the years and confusion between instructions for the
Pledge of Allegiance versus the National Anthem, throughout most of the 20th
century many people simply stood at attention or with their hands folded in
front of them during the playing of the Anthem, and when reciting the Pledge
they would hold their hand (or hat) over their heart. After 9/11, the custom
of placing the hand over the heart during the playing of the national anthem
became nearly universal.[63][64][65]

Since 1998, federal law (viz., the United States Code [36
U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_36_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 36 of the United
States Code") [§ 301](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/301)) states
that during a rendition of the national anthem, when the flag is displayed,
all present including those in uniform should stand at attention; Non-military
service individuals should face the flag with the right hand over the heart;
Members of the Armed Forces and veterans who are present and not in uniform
may render the military salute; military service persons not in uniform should
remove their headdress with their right hand and hold the headdress at the
left shoulder, the hand being over the heart; and Members of the Armed Forces
and veterans who are in uniform should give the military salute at the first
note of the anthem and maintain that position until the last note. The law
further provides that when the flag is not displayed, all present should face
toward the music and act in the same manner they would if the flag were
displayed. Military law requires all vehicles on the installation to stop when
the song is played and all individuals outside to stand at attention and face
the direction of the music and either salute, in uniform, or place the right
hand over the heart, if out of uniform. The law was amended in 2008, and since
allows military veterans to salute out of uniform, as well.[66][67]

The text of [36 U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_36_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 36 of
the United States Code") [§
301](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/301) is suggestive and not
regulatory in nature. Failure to follow the suggestions is not a violation of
the law. This behavioral requirement for the national anthem is subject to the
same [First Amendment](/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"First Amendment to the United States Constitution") controversies that
surround the [Pledge of
Allegiance](/wiki/Pledge_of_Allegiance_\(United_States\) "Pledge of Allegiance
\(United States\)").[68] For example, [Jehovah's
Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses") do not sing the
national anthem, though they are taught that standing is an "ethical decision"
that individual believers must make based on their "conscience."[69][70][71]

## Protests

Main article: [U.S. national anthem
protests](/wiki/U.S._national_anthem_protests "U.S. national anthem protests")

### 1968 Olympics Black Power salute

Main article: [1968 Olympics Black Power
salute](/wiki/1968_Olympics_Black_Power_salute "1968 Olympics Black Power
salute")

The 1968 Olympics Black Power salute was a political demonstration conducted
by [African-American](/wiki/African-American "African-American") athletes
[Tommie Smith](/wiki/Tommie_Smith "Tommie Smith") and [John
Carlos](/wiki/John_Carlos "John Carlos") during their medal ceremony at the
[1968 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics "1968 Summer Olympics") in
the [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario "Estadio
Olímpico Universitario") in [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City").
After having won gold and bronze medals respectively in the
[200-meter](/wiki/200_metres_at_the_Olympics "200 metres at the Olympics")
running event, they turned on the podium to face their flags, and to hear the
American national anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner". Each athlete [raised a
black-gloved fist](/wiki/Raised_fist "Raised fist"), and kept them raised
until the anthem had finished. In addition, Smith, Carlos, and Australian
silver medalist [Peter Norman](/wiki/Peter_Norman "Peter Norman") all wore
human rights badges on their jackets. In his autobiography, _Silent Gesture_ ,
Smith stated that the gesture was not a "[Black Power](/wiki/Black_Power
"Black Power")" salute, but a "human rights salute". The event is regarded as
one of the most overtly political statements in the history of the modern
[Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games").[72]

### 2016 protests

Main article: [U.S. national anthem protests
(2016–present)](/wiki/U.S._national_anthem_protests_\(2016%E2%80%93present\)
"U.S. national anthem protests \(2016–present\)")

Politically motivated protests of the national anthem began in the [National
Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")
(NFL) after [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco
49ers") [quarterback](/wiki/Quarterback "Quarterback") (QB) [Colin
Kaepernick](/wiki/Colin_Kaepernick "Colin Kaepernick") sat during the anthem,
as opposed to the tradition of standing, in response to police brutality in
America, before his team's third
[preseason](/wiki/National_Football_League_preseason "National Football League
preseason") game of [2016](/wiki/2016_NFL_season "2016 NFL season").
Kaepernick also sat during the first two preseason games, but he went
unnoticed.[73]

### NAACP call to remove the national anthem

In November 2017, the California Chapter of the [NAACP](/wiki/NAACP "NAACP")
called on Congress to remove "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national
anthem. Alice Huffman, California NAACP president said: "it's racist; it
doesn't represent our community, it's anti-black."[74] The third stanza of the
anthem, which is rarely sung and few know, contains the words, "No refuge
could save the hireling and slave, From the terror of flight, or the gloom of
the grave:", which some interpret as racist. The organization was still
seeking a representative to sponsor the legislation in Congress at the time of
their announcement.

## Translations

As a result of immigration to the United States and the incorporation of non-
English speaking people into the country, the lyrics of the song have been
translated into other languages. In 1861, it was translated into German.[75]
The Library of Congress also has record of a Spanish-language version from
1919.[76] It has since been translated into [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language
"Hebrew language")[77] and [Yiddish](/wiki/Yiddish_language "Yiddish
language") by Jewish immigrants,[78] Latin American Spanish (with [one
version](/wiki/Nuestro_Himno "Nuestro Himno") popularized during [immigration
reform protests in 2006](/wiki/2006_United_States_immigration_reform_protests
"2006 United States immigration reform protests")),[79] French by
[Acadians](/wiki/Acadian "Acadian") of Louisiana,[80]
[Samoan](/wiki/Samoan_language "Samoan language"),[81] and Irish.[82] The
third verse of the anthem has also been translated into [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin").[83]

With regard to the indigenous languages of North America, there are versions
[in
Navajo](https://nv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dah_Naat%CA%BCa%CA%BC%C3%AD_S%C7%AB%CA%BC_bi%C5%82_Sinil
"nv:Dah Naatʼaʼí Sǫʼ bił Sinil")[84][85][86] and Cherokee.[87]
